text:
To minimize health risks during the COVID-19 pandemic, the Cavaliers will not
be included in a 22-team restart plan the NBA will submit to the Board of
Governors today, according to multiple reports.

The format to resume was reported by Shams Charania of The Athletic and Adrian
Wojnarowski of ESPN in advance of today's 12:30 p.m. video conference. Three-
fourths of the owners are required for approval and the plan is expected to
pass, Jeff Zillgitt of USA TODAY reported. The NBA Players Association must
also ratify it.

According to Wojnarowski, the league will bring together 13 Western Conference
teams and nine from the Eastern Conference in Orlando, Florida, with all
playing eight regular season games to determine playoff seeds. That part of
the schedule will resemble an NCAA Tournament, with multiple games per day
through the first round of the playoffs.

According to reports, if the ninth seed is more than four games behind the
eighth, No. 8 makes the postseason, but fewer than four games would require a
play-in tournament. In case of a play-in, there would be a single elimination
for the ninth seed and a double elimination for the eighth seed, Zillgitt
said.

Zillgitt reported that a 2½-week training camp at the ESPN Wide World of
Sports Complex just outside Orlando is being proposed before games resume.

Those on the playoff bubble that will be included, according to reports, are
the Portland Trail Blazers (29-37), New Orleans Pelicans (28-36), Sacramento
Kings (28-36), San Antonio Spurs (27-36) and Phoenix Suns (26-39) in the West
and the Washington Wizards (24-40) in the East. The Wizards are 5½ games
behind the current eighth seeded Orlando Magic (30-35), and the Memphis
Grizzlies (32-33) are No. 8 in the West.

The Cavs compiled a 5-6 record under coach J.B. Bickerstaff, who took over
after John Beilein stepped down, but they own the second-worst record in the
league (19-46).

Bickerstaff and several Cavs, including Kevin Love, Larry Nance Jr. and Collin
Sexton, have said during the pandemic they hoped their season wasn't over.

"With our guys in particular, any minute that we can get working with each
other is beneficial to us," Bickerstaff said on May 6.

"Eleven games, it's not enough. We know we were heading in the right
direction."

According to ESPN, play will begin on July 31, with Oct. 12 the last date for
a possible Game 7 of the NBA Finals.

The Athletic reported that the draft lottery and combine will be held in
August.

The Cavs can select no lower than sixth and have a 14 percent chance of
getting the No. 1 pick.

The league suspended play on March 11 after Rudy Gobert of the Utah Jazz
tested positive for the virus; teammate Donovan Mitchell tested positive hours
later.

According to Charania, the NBA is still debating several proposals to maintain
social distancing, including not allowing players to shower at the arena,
having them spread out in rows on the bench and prohibiting guests until the
playoffs.

title: 22-team NBA plan won't include Cleveland
html:
To minimize health risks during the COVID-19 pandemic, the Cavaliers will not be included in a 22-team restart plan the NBA will submit to the Board of Governors today, according to multiple reports.

The format to resume was reported by Shams Charania of The Athletic and Adrian Wojnarowski of ESPN in advance of today's 12:30 p.m. video conference. Three-fourths of the owners are required for approval and the plan is expected to pass, Jeff Zillgitt of USA TODAY reported. The NBA Players Association must also ratify it.

According to Wojnarowski, the league will bring together 13 Western Conference teams and nine from the Eastern Conference in Orlando, Florida, with all playing eight regular season games to determine playoff seeds. That part of the schedule will resemble an NCAA Tournament, with multiple games per day through the first round of the playoffs.

According to reports, if the ninth seed is more than four games behind the eighth, No. 8 makes the postseason, but fewer than four games would require a play-in tournament. In case of a play-in, there would be a single elimination for the ninth seed and a double elimination for the eighth seed, Zillgitt said.

Zillgitt reported that a 2½-week training camp at the ESPN Wide World of Sports Complex just outside Orlando is being proposed before games resume.

Those on the playoff bubble that will be included, according to reports, are the Portland Trail Blazers (29-37), New Orleans Pelicans (28-36), Sacramento Kings (28-36), San Antonio Spurs (27-36) and Phoenix Suns (26-39) in the West and the Washington Wizards (24-40) in the East. The Wizards are 5½ games behind the current eighth seeded Orlando Magic (30-35), and the Memphis Grizzlies (32-33) are No. 8 in the West.

The Cavs compiled a 5-6 record under coach J.B. Bickerstaff, who took over after John Beilein stepped down, but they own the second-worst record in the league (19-46).

Bickerstaff and several Cavs, including Kevin Love, Larry Nance Jr. and Collin Sexton, have said during the pandemic they hoped their season wasn't over.

"With our guys in particular, any minute that we can get working with each other is beneficial to us," Bickerstaff said on May 6.

"Eleven games, it's not enough. We know we were heading in the right direction."

According to ESPN, play will begin on July 31, with Oct. 12 the last date for a possible Game 7 of the NBA Finals.

The Athletic reported that the draft lottery and combine will be held in August.

The Cavs can select no lower than sixth and have a 14 percent chance of getting the No. 1 pick.

The league suspended play on March 11 after Rudy Gobert of the Utah Jazz tested positive for the virus; teammate Donovan Mitchell tested positive hours later.

According to Charania, the NBA is still debating several proposals to maintain social distancing, including not allowing players to shower at the arena, having them spread out in rows on the bench and prohibiting guests until the playoffs.
